meanings.definition: To surpass in number or population.
meanings.sent1: The new school in town will quickly outpeople the old one.
meanings.sent2: The city's growth will eventually outpeople the small town nearby.
meanings.sent3: The marathon runners seemed to outpeople the spectators cheering them on.
meanings.sent4: The colorful flowers outpeopled the dull grass in the garden.
meanings.sent5: The enthusiastic fans outpeopled the quiet library with their cheers.

meanings.definition: To exceed in social status or influence.
meanings.sent1: Her kindness and generosity outpeople her wealth and possessions.
meanings.sent2: The wise leader's influence outpeopled that of the other council members.
meanings.sent3: The humble teacher managed to outpeople the arrogant principal in the students' eyes.
meanings.sent4: His charisma outpeopled his lack of experience in the business world.
meanings.sent5: The artist's talent outpeopled the critics' harsh reviews.

meanings.definition: Those who are not part of a particular group or community.
meanings.sent1: The outpeople gathered at the edge of the village, seeking shelter.
meanings.sent2: The outpeople often felt lonely and isolated from the rest of the town.
meanings.sent3: The outpeople decided to start their own community where everyone was welcome.
meanings.sent4: The outpeople formed a close-knit group to support each other in times of need.
meanings.sent5: The outpeople found solace in their shared experiences and understanding.
